title: New Tacx Neo 3M trainer rocks and rolls and the Tacx app gets better too
content:
Cyclist
New Tacx Neo 3M trainer rocks and rolls and the Tacx app gets better too

Garmin has announced its latest Tacx Neo 3M indoor trainer which, like the recently launched Wahoo Kickr Move, provides forward and backward motion as you ride as well as side-to-side tilting, with Garmin claiming a more comfortable ride experience for a wider range of users.

The new trainer is priced at £1,749.99 / $1,999.99 / €1,999.99.

Garmin has also integrated the new trainer more closely with its Tacx training app, to which it has added new features including group rides and leaderboards, on top of the existing real world video. The Neo 3M plays nice with Zwift, TrainerRoad, Rouvy or whatever else your indoor training poison may be.

Garmin says that the Tacx Neo 3M, as with the previous generation Tacx Neo 2T, can simulate surfaces from roads to cobbles, gravel and even cattle grids, while it will allow you to ride simulated gradients of up to 25% and sprint at a maximum 2,200 watts. 

As with Tacx’s previous generation Neo trainers, the Neo 3M can be operated with or without a power supply. You need mains power to simulate descents and non-road surfaces though, and it also leads to a faster response when operating your trainer in ERG mode. Garmin says that it has upgraded the power supply and the trainer’s cooling so that it can drive the motor faster for a more responsive ride feel.

The +/- 1% claimed power accuracy is said to be achieved over a greater range of power output/cadence combinations than the Neo 2T and Garmin says that ERG mode also responds faster. As a cool extra, the trainer shines an LED array at the floor just ahead of your bottom bracket, which turns from blue through to red as you ramp up the watts.

The trainer motion can be locked out via two knobs at the rear of the trainer, should you prefer a more planted platform. Garmin commissioned usability assessments by a Swedish company, which found that riders felt that the movement made for a more comfortable ride experience in all except 3-second sprint efforts. There was no measured loss in ride efficiency.

If you want to avoid connection drop-outs when riding or racing, Garmin will sell an Ethernet/Wi-Fi dongle akin to the Wahoo Direct Connect device as an accessory for the Neo 3M, allowing for a wired or Wi-Fi connection to the outside world.

The Tacx Neo 3M will be supplied with an 11-speed cassette, although you can fit a 12-speed cassette to match your drivetrain. There’s a new flippable front wheel riser block, with one side handling road and gravel tyres and the other mountain bike tyres of up to 61mm width. 

Garmin says that the trainer is easy to move around, with a centrally located carrying handle and folding side legs.

Enhancements to the Tacx app

Garmin also looks to be gunning for the Wahoo Systm training app with enhancements to the Tacx training app. This gives you a mix of content, including real world video of famous ride locations, which is available in standard definition or, when you pay for the premium tier, in high definition.

The Neo 3M’s packaging includes a 3D barcode, which links you up to content to make setup easier. It also gives you three months’ free access to the premium tier of the Tacx app, for added functionality and high definition ride video.

In addition, the Tacx app now has increased integration with the Garmin Connect app, so that once the barcode is scanned on setup, the trainer will automatically be added to your list of Garmin devices in Garmin Connect. Workouts scheduled in Garmin Connect will also be automatically made available in the Tacx app.

Tacx Neo 3M pricing

The Tacx Neo 3M is priced at £1,749.99 / $1,999.99 / €1,999.99. 

The Neo 2T was already a premium product, with its neodymium magnets and virtual flywheel a sophisticated solution for resistance generation. The Tacx Neo Motion Plates, which allow side-to-side motion, are an (expensive) extra to the Neo 2T, while side-to-side and fore-and-aft motion are built into the new Neo 3M, so the trainer’s lofty price should perhaps not come as a surprise.

Once your free three month subscription ends, the Tacx app is priced at £9.99 / $9.99 / €9.99 per month for standard access or £13.99 / $13.99 / €13.99 for the premium tier. You can also pay annually, in which case prices are £99.99 / $99.99 / €99.99 for standard access or £139.99 / $139.99 / €139.99 for premium access.

As with the Wahoo Kickr Move and the original Wahoo Kickr, the new Tacx Neo 3M trainer will be an addition to the range rather than a replacement for the previous Neo 2T, which will continue to be sold.
